1.name: Aerospace Engineering and Operations Technicians
1.brief: Aerospace engineering and operations technicians operate and maintain equipment used in developing, testing, and producing new aircraft and spacecraft. Increasingly, these workers are using computer-based modeling and simulation tools and processes in their work.

2.name: Aerospace Engineers
2.brief: Aerospace engineers design primarily aircraft, spacecraft, satellites, and missiles. In addition, they test prototypes to make sure that they function according to design.

3.name: Agricultural Engineers
3.brief: Agricultural engineers attempt to solve agricultural problems concerning power supplies, the efficiency of machinery, the use of structures and facilities, pollution and environmental issues, and the storage and processing of agricultural products.
similar_occupations: Farmers, Ranchers, and Other Agricultural Managers

4.name: Architects
4.brief: Architects plan and design houses, factories, office buildings, and other structures.

5.name: Biomedical Engineers
5.brief: Biomedical engineers combine engineering principles with medical and biological sciences to design and create equipment, devices, computer systems, and software used in healthcare.

6.name: Cartographers and Photogrammetrists
6.brief: Cartographers and photogrammetrists collect, measure, and interpret geographic information in order to create and update maps and charts for regional planning, education, emergency response, and other purposes.

7.name: Chemical Engineers
7.brief: Chemical engineers apply the principles of chemistry, biology, physics, and math to solve problems that involve the production or use of chemicals, fuel, drugs, food, and many other products. They design processes and equipment for large-scale manufacturing, plan and test production methods and byproducts treatment, and direct facility operations.

8.name: Civil Engineering Technicians
8.brief: Civil engineering technicians help civil engineers to plan, design, and build highways, bridges, utilities, and other infrastructure projects. They also help to plan, design, and build commercial, industrial, residential, and land development projects.

9.name: Civil Engineers
9.brief: Civil engineers design, build, supervise, operate, and maintain construction projects and systems in the public and private sector, including roads, buildings, airports, tunnels, dams, bridges, and systems for water supply and sewage treatment.

10.name: Computer Hardware Engineers
10.brief: Computer hardware engineers research, design, develop, and test computer systems and components such as processors, circuit boards, memory devices, networks, and routers. These engineers discover new directions in computer hardware, which generate rapid advances in computer technology.

11.name: Drafters
11.brief: Drafters use software to convert the designs of engineers and architects into technical drawings. Most workers specialize in architectural, civil, electrical, or mechanical drafting and use technical drawings to help design everything from microchips to skyscrapers.
similar_occupations: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers

12.name: Electrical and Electronics Engineering Technicians
12.brief: Electrical and electronics engineering technicians help engineers design and develop computers, communications equipment, medical monitoring devices, navigational equipment, and other electrical and electronic equipment. They often work in product evaluation and testing, using measuring and diagnostic devices to adjust, test, and repair equipment. They are also involved in the manufacture and deployment of equipment for automation.
similar_occupations: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers

13.name: Electrical and Electronics Engineers
13.brief: Electrical engineers design, develop, test, and supervise the manufacturing of electrical equipment, such as electric motors, radar and navigation systems, communications systems, and power generation equipment. Electronics engineers design and develop electronic equipment, such as broadcast and communications systemsâfrom portable music players to global positioning systems (GPSs).
similar_occupations: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers

14.name: Electro-mechanical Technicians
14.brief: Electro-mechanical technicians combine knowledge of mechanical technology with knowledge of electrical and electronic circuits. They operate, test, and maintain unmanned, automated, robotic, or electromechanical equipment.
similar_occupations: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers
Machinists and Tool and Die Makers

15.name: Environmental Engineering Technicians
15.brief: Environmental engineering technicians carry out the plans that environmental engineers develop. They test, operate, and, if necessary, modify equipment used to prevent or clean up environmental pollution. They may collect samples for testing, or they may work to mitigate sources of environmental pollution.

16.name: Environmental Engineers
16.brief: Environmental engineers use the principles of engineering, soil science, biology, and chemistry to develop solutions to environmental problems. They are involved in efforts to improve recycling, waste disposal, public health, and water and air pollution control.

17.name: Health and Safety Engineers
17.brief: Health and safety engineers develop procedures and design systems to prevent people from getting sick or injured and to keep property from being damaged. They combine knowledge of systems engineering and of health and safety to make sure that chemicals, machinery, software, furniture, and other consumer products will not cause harm to people or damage to buildings.

18.name: Industrial Engineering Technicians
18.brief: Industrial engineering technicians help industrial engineers implement designs to use personnel, materials, and machines effectively in factories, stores, healthcare organizations, repair shops, and offices. They prepare machinery and equipment layouts, plan workflows, conduct statistical production studies, and analyze production costs.

19.name: Industrial Engineers
19.brief: Industrial engineers find ways to eliminate wastefulness in production processes. They devise efficient systems that integrate workers, machines, materials, information, and energy to make a product or provide a service.

20.name: Landscape Architects
20.brief: Landscape architects design parks and the outdoor spaces of campuses, recreational facilities, private homes, and other open areas.

21.name: Marine Engineers and Naval Architects
21.brief: Marine engineers and naval architects design, build, and maintain ships from aircraft carriers to submarines, from sailboats to tankers. Marine engineers are primarily responsible for the internal systems of a ship, such as propulsion, electrical, refrigeration, and steering. Naval architects are primarily responsible for the ship design, including the form, structure, and stability of hulls.

22.name: Materials Engineers
22.brief: Materials engineers develop, process, and test materials used to create a wide range of products, from computer chips and aircraft wings to golf clubs and biomedical devices. They study the properties and structures of metals, ceramics, plastics, composites, nanomaterials (extremely small substances), and other substances to create new materials that meet certain mechanical, electrical, and chemical requirements.

23.name: Mechanical Engineering Technicians
23.brief: Mechanical engineering technicians help mechanical engineers design, develop, test, and manufacture mechanical devices, including tools, engines, and machines. They may make sketches and rough layouts, record and analyze data, make calculations and estimates, and report their findings.
similar_occupations: Machinists and Tool and Die Makers

24.name: Mechanical Engineers
24.brief: Mechanical engineering is one of the broadest engineering disciplines. Mechanical engineers design, develop, build, and test mechanical and thermal sensors and devices, including tools, engines, and machines.

25.name: Mining and Geological Engineers
25.brief: Mining and geological engineers design mines to safely and efficiently remove minerals such as coal and metals for use in manufacturing and utilities.

26.name: Nuclear Engineers
26.brief: Nuclear engineers research and develop the processes, instruments, and systems used to derive benefits from nuclear energy and radiation. Many of these engineers find industrial and medical uses for radioactive materialsâfor example, in equipment used in medical diagnosis and treatment.

27.name: Petroleum Engineers
27.brief: Petroleum engineers design and develop methods for extracting oil and gas from deposits below the Earthâs surface. Petroleum engineers also find new ways to extract oil and gas from older wells.

28.name: Surveying and Mapping Technicians
28.brief: Surveying and mapping technicians collect data and make maps of the Earthâs surface. Surveying technicians visit sites to take measurements of the land. Mapping technicians use geographic data to create maps. They both assist surveyors, cartographers, and photogrammetrists.

29.name: Surveyors
29.brief: Surveyors make precise measurements to determine property boundaries. They provide data relevant to the shape and contour of the Earthâs surface for engineering, mapmaking, and construction projects.

30.name: Art Directors
30.brief: Art directors are responsible for the visual style and images in magazines, newspapers, product packaging, and movie and television productions. They create the overall design of a project and direct others who develop artwork and layouts.

31.name: Craft and Fine Artists
31.brief: Craft and fine artists use a variety of materials and techniques to create art for sale and exhibition. Craft artists create handmade objects, such as pottery, glassware, textiles, and other objects that are designed to be functional. Fine artists, including painters, sculptors, and illustrators, create original works of art for their aesthetic value, rather than for a functional one.
similar_occupations: Jewelers and Precious Stone and Metal Workers

32.name: Fashion Designers
32.brief: Fashion designers create original clothing, accessories, and footwear. They sketch designs, select fabrics and patterns, and give instructions on how to make the products they designed.
similar_occupations: Jewelers and Precious Stone and Metal Workers

33.name: Floral Designers
33.brief: Floral designers, also called florists, cut and arrange live, dried, and silk flowers and greenery to make decorative displays. They also help customers select flowers, containers, ribbons, and other accessories.

34.name: Graphic Designers
34.brief: Graphic designers create visual concepts, using computer software or by hand, to communicate ideas that inspire, inform, and captivate consumers. They develop the overall layout and production design for various applications such as advertisements, brochures, magazines, and corporate reports.

35.name: Industrial Designers
35.brief: Industrial designers develop the concepts for manufactured products, such as cars, home appliances, and toys. They combine art, business, and engineering to make products that people use every day. Industrial designers consider the function, aesthetics, production costs, and the usability of products when developing new product concepts.

36.name: Interior Designers
36.brief: Interior designers make interior spaces functional, safe, and beautiful by determining space requirements and selecting decorative items, such as colors, lighting, and materials. They read blueprints and must be aware of building codes and inspection regulations, as well as universal accessibility standards.

37.name: Multimedia Artists and Animators
37.brief: Multimedia artists and animators create animation and visual effects for television, movies, video games, and other forms of media.

38.name: Grounds Maintenance Workers
38.brief: Grounds maintenance workers ensure that the grounds of houses, businesses, and parks are attractive, orderly, and healthy in order to provide a pleasant outdoor environment.
similar_occupations: Farmers, Ranchers, and Other Agricultural Managers

39.name: Janitors and Building Cleaners
39.brief: Janitors and building cleaners keep many types of buildings clean, orderly, and in good condition.

40.name: Pest Control Workers
40.brief: Pest control workers remove unwanted creatures, such as roaches, rats, ants, bedbugs, and termites that infest buildings and surrounding areas.

41.name: Accountants and Auditors
41.brief: Accountants and auditors prepare and examine financial records. They ensure that financial records are accurate and that taxes are paid properly and on time. Accountants and auditors assess financial operations and work to help ensure that organizations run efficiently.
similar_occupations: Tax Examiners and Collectors, and Revenue Agents

42.name: Appraisers and Assessors of Real Estate
42.brief: Appraisers and assessors of real estate provide an estimate of the value of land and the buildings on the land usually before it is sold, mortgaged, taxed, insured, or developed.
similar_occupations: Claims Adjusters, Appraisers, Examiners, and Investigators
Real Estate Brokers and Sales Agents

43.name: Budget Analysts
43.brief: Budget analysts help public and private institutions organize their finances. They prepare budget reports and monitor institutional spending.
similar_occupations: Tax Examiners and Collectors, and Revenue Agents

44.name: Buyers and Purchasing Agents
44.brief: Buyers and purchasing agents buy products and services for organizations to use or resell. They evaluate suppliers, negotiate contracts, and review the quality of products.

45.name: Claims Adjusters, Appraisers, Examiners, and Investigators
45.brief: Claims adjusters, appraisers, examiners, and investigators evaluate insurance claims. They decide whether an insurance company must pay a claim, and if so, how much.
similar_occupations: Appraisers and Assessors of Real Estate

46.name: Compensation, Benefits, and Job Analysis Specialists
46.brief: Compensation, benefits, and job analysis specialists conduct an organizationâs compensation and benefits programs. They also evaluate position descriptions to determine details such as a personâs classification and salary.

47.name: Cost Estimators
47.brief: Cost estimators collect and analyze data in order to estimate the time, money, materials, and labor required to manufacture a product, construct a building, or provide a service. They generally specialize in a particular product or industry.
similar_occupations: Claims Adjusters, Appraisers, Examiners, and Investigators

48.name: Financial Analysts
48.brief: Financial analysts provide guidance to businesses and individuals making investment decisions. They assess the performance of stocks, bonds, and other types of investments.
similar_occupations: Securities, Commodities, and Financial Services Sales Agents

49.name: Financial Examiners
49.brief: Financial examiners ensure compliance with laws governing financial institutions and transactions. They review balance sheets, evaluate the risk level of loans, and assess bank management.
similar_occupations: Tax Examiners and Collectors, and Revenue Agents

50.name: Fundraisers
50.brief: Fundraisers organize events and campaigns to raise money and other donations for an organization. They may design promotional materials and increase awareness of an organizationâs work, goals, and financial needs.

51.name: Human Resources Specialists
51.brief: Human resources specialists recruit, screen, interview, and place workers. They often handle other human resources work, such as those related to employee relations, compensation and benefits, and training.
similar_occupations: Compensation, Benefits, and Job Analysis Specialists
Tax Examiners and Collectors, and Revenue Agents

52.name: Insurance Underwriters
52.brief: Insurance underwriters decide whether to provide insurance and under what terms. They evaluate insurance applications and determine coverage amounts and premiums.
similar_occupations: Claims Adjusters, Appraisers, Examiners, and Investigators

53.name: Labor Relations Specialists
53.brief: Labor relations specialists interpret and administer labor contracts regarding issues such as wages and salaries, healthcare, pensions, and union and management practices.
similar_occupations: Compensation, Benefits, and Job Analysis Specialists

54.name: Loan Officers
54.brief: Loan officers evaluate, authorize, or recommend approval of loan applications for people and businesses.
similar_occupations: Tax Examiners and Collectors, and Revenue Agents
Securities, Commodities, and Financial Services Sales Agents
Real Estate Brokers and Sales Agents

55.name: Logisticians
55.brief: Logisticians analyze and coordinate an organizationâs supply chainâthe system that moves a product from supplier to consumer. They manage the entire life cycle of a product, which includes how a product is acquired, distributed, allocated, and delivered.

57.name: Market Research Analysts
57.brief: Market research analysts study market conditions to examine potential sales of a product or service. They help companies understand what products people want, who will buy them, and at what price.

58.name: Meeting, Convention, and Event Planners
58.brief: Meeting, convention, and event planners coordinate all aspects of events and professional meetings. They arrange meeting locations, transportation, and other details.

59.name: Personal Financial Advisors
59.brief: Personal financial advisors provide advice on investments, insurance, mortgages, college savings, estate planning, taxes, and retirement to help individuals manage their finances.
similar_occupations: Real Estate Brokers and Sales Agents
Securities, Commodities, and Financial Services Sales Agents

60.name: Tax Examiners and Collectors, and Revenue Agents
60.brief: Tax examiners and collectors, and revenue agents ensure that federal, state, and local governments get their tax money from businesses and citizens. They review tax returns, conduct audits, identify taxes owed, and collect overdue tax payments.

61.name: Training and Development Specialists
61.brief: Training and development specialists plan, conduct, and administer programs that train employees and improve their skills and knowledge.
similar_occupations: Compensation, Benefits, and Job Analysis Specialists

62.name: Health Educators and Community Health Workers
62.brief: Health educators teach people about behaviors that promote wellness. They develop and implement strategies to improve the health of individuals and communities. Community health workers collect data and discuss health concerns with members of specific populations or communities.
similar_occupations: Mental Health Counselors and Marriage and Family Therapists
Substance Abuse and Behavioral Disorder Counselors

63.name: Mental Health Counselors and Marriage and Family Therapists
63.brief: Mental health counselors and marriage and family therapists help people manage and overcome mental and emotional disorders and problems with family and other relationships. They listen to clients and ask questions to help the clients understand their problems and develop strategies to improve their lives.
similar_occupations: Substance Abuse and Behavioral Disorder Counselors

64.name: Probation Officers and Correctional Treatment Specialists
64.brief: Probation officers and correctional treatment specialists monitor and work with probationers to prevent them from committing new crimes.
similar_occupations: Substance Abuse and Behavioral Disorder Counselors

65.name: Rehabilitation Counselors
65.brief: Rehabilitation counselors help people with physical, mental, developmental, and emotional disabilities live independently. They work with clients to overcome or manage the personal, social, or psychological effects of disabilities on employment or independent living.
similar_occupations: Mental Health Counselors and Marriage and Family Therapists
Substance Abuse and Behavioral Disorder Counselors

66.name: School and Career Counselors
66.brief: School counselors help students develop academic and social skills and succeed in school. Career counselors assist people with the process of making career decisions by helping them develop skills or choose a career or educational program.
similar_occupations: Mental Health Counselors and Marriage and Family Therapists
Substance Abuse and Behavioral Disorder Counselors

67.name: Social and Human Service Assistants
similar_occupations: Health Educators and Community Health Workers
Mental Health Counselors and Marriage and Family Therapists
Probation Officers and Correctional Treatment Specialists
Substance Abuse and Behavioral Disorder Counselors

68.name: Social Workers
68.brief: Social workers help people solve and cope with problems in their everyday lives. One group of social workersâclinical social workersâalso diagnose and treat mental, behavioral, and emotional issues.
similar_occupations: Health Educators and Community Health Workers
Mental Health Counselors and Marriage and Family Therapists
Probation Officers and Correctional Treatment Specialists
Substance Abuse and Behavioral Disorder Counselors

69.name: Substance Abuse and Behavioral Disorder Counselors
69.brief: Substance abuse and behavioral disorder counselors advise people who suffer from alcoholism, drug addiction, eating disorders, or other behavioral problems. They provide treatment and support to help the client recover from addiction or modify problem behaviors.
similar_occupations: Mental Health Counselors and Marriage and Family Therapists

70.name: Computer and Information Research Scientists
70.brief: Computer and information research scientists invent and design new approaches to computing technology and find innovative uses for existing technology. They study and solve complex problems in computing for business, medicine, science, and other fields.

71.name: Computer Network Architects
71.brief: Computer network architects design and build data communication networks, including local area networks (LANs), wide area networks (WANs), and intranets. These networks range from small connections between two offices to next-generation networking capabilities such as a cloud infrastructure that serves multiple customers.

72.name: Computer Programmers
72.brief: Computer programmers write and test code that allows computer applications and software programs to function properly. They turn the program designs created by software developers and engineers into instructions that a computer can follow.

73.name: Computer Support Specialists
73.brief: Computer support specialists provide help and advice to people and organizations using computer software or equipment. Some, called computer network support specialists, support information technology (IT) employees within their organization. Others, called computer user support specialists, assist non-IT users who are having computer problems.

74.name: Computer Systems Analysts
74.brief: Computer systems analysts study an organizationâs current computer systems and procedures and design information systems solutions to help the organization operate more efficiently and effectively. They bring business and information technology (IT) together by understanding the needs and limitations of both.

75.name: Database Administrators
75.brief: Database administrators (DBAs) use specialized software to store and organize data, such as financial information and customer shipping records. They make sure that data are available to users and are secure from unauthorized access.

76.name: Information Security Analysts
76.brief: Information security analysts plan and carry out security measures to protect an organizationâs computer networks and systems. Their responsibilities are continually expanding as the number of cyberattacks increases.

77.name: Network and Computer Systems Administrators
77.brief: Computer networks are critical parts of almost every organization. Network and computer systems administrators are responsible for the day-to-day operation of these networks.

78.name: Software Developers
78.brief: Software developers are the creative minds behind computer programs. Some develop the applications that allow people to do specific tasks on a computer or another device. Others develop the underlying systems that run the devices or that control networks.

79.name: Web Developers
79.brief: Web developers design and create websites. They are responsible for the look of the site. They are also responsible for the siteâs technical aspects, such as its performance and capacity, which are measures of a websiteâs speed and how much traffic the site can handle. In addition, web developers may create content for the site.

80.name: Boilermakers
80.brief: Boilermakers assemble, install, and repair boilers, closed vats, and other large vessels or containers that hold liquids and gases.
similar_occupations: Machinists and Tool and Die Makers
Industrial Machinery Mechanics, Machinery Maintenance Workers, and Millwrights

81.name: Masonry Workers
similar_occupations: Drywall and Ceiling Tile Installers, and Tapers
Flooring Installers and Tile and Marble Setters

82.name: Carpenters
82.brief: Carpenters construct and repair building frameworks and structuresâsuch as stairways, doorframes, partitions, rafters, and bridge supportsâmade from wood and other materials. They also may install kitchen cabinets, siding, and drywall.
similar_occupations: Drywall and Ceiling Tile Installers, and Tapers
Flooring Installers and Tile and Marble Setters
Industrial Machinery Mechanics, Machinery Maintenance Workers, and Millwrights

83.name: Construction and Building Inspectors
83.brief: Construction and building inspectors ensure that construction meets local and national building codes and ordinances, zoning regulations, and contract specifications.
similar_occupations: Appraisers and Assessors of Real Estate

84.name: Construction Equipment Operators
84.brief: Construction equipment operators drive, maneuver, or control the heavy machinery used to construct roads, bridges, buildings, and other structures.
similar_occupations: Farmers, Ranchers, and Other Agricultural Managers

85.name: Construction Laborers and Helpers
85.brief: Construction laborers and helpers perform many tasks that require physical labor on construction sites.
similar_occupations: Flooring Installers and Tile and Marble Setters

86.name: Drywall and Ceiling Tile Installers, and Tapers
86.brief: Drywall and ceiling tile installers hang wallboard and install ceiling tile inside buildings. Tapers prepare the wallboard for painting, using tape and other materials. Many workers both install and tape wallboard.
similar_occupations: Flooring Installers and Tile and Marble Setters

87.name: Electricians
87.brief: Electricians install, maintain, and repair electrical power, communications, lighting, and control systems in homes, businesses, and factories.
similar_occupations: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers
Heating, Air Conditioning, and Refrigeration Mechanics and Installers

88.name: Elevator Installers and Repairers
88.brief: Elevator installers and repairers install, fix, and maintain elevators, escalators, moving walkways, and other lifts.
similar_occupations: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers
Industrial Machinery Mechanics, Machinery Maintenance Workers, and Millwrights

89.name: Glaziers
89.brief: Glaziers install glass in windows, skylights, and other fixtures in storefronts and buildings.
similar_occupations: Flooring Installers and Tile and Marble Setters

90.name: Hazardous Materials Removal Workers
90.brief: Hazardous materials (hazmat) removal workers identify and dispose of asbestos, lead, radioactive waste, and other hazardous materials. They also neutralize and clean up materials that are flammable, corrosive, or toxic.
similar_occupations: Power Plant Operators, Distributors, and Dispatchers
Water and Wastewater Treatment Plant and System Operators

91.name: Insulation Workers
91.brief: Insulation workers install and replace the materials used to insulate buildings to help control and maintain the temperatures in buildings.
similar_occupations: Drywall and Ceiling Tile Installers, and Tapers

92.name: Painters, Construction and Maintenance
92.brief: Painters apply paint, stain, and coatings to walls and ceilings, buildings, bridges, and other structures.
similar_occupations: Drywall and Ceiling Tile Installers, and Tapers

93.name: Plumbers, Pipefitters, and Steamfitters
93.brief: Plumbers, pipefitters, and steamfitters install and repair pipes that carry liquids or gases to, from, and within businesses, homes, and factories.
similar_occupations: Heating, Air Conditioning, and Refrigeration Mechanics and Installers

94.name: Roofers
94.brief: Roofers replace, repair, and install the roofs of buildings using a variety of materials, including shingles, bitumen, and metal.
similar_occupations: Drywall and Ceiling Tile Installers, and Tapers
Flooring Installers and Tile and Marble Setters

95.name: Sheet Metal Workers
95.brief: Sheet metal workers fabricate or install products that are made from thin metal sheets, such as ducts used in heating and air conditioning systems.
similar_occupations: Heating, Air Conditioning, and Refrigeration Mechanics and Installers
Machinists and Tool and Die Makers

97.name: Ironworkers
97.brief: Ironworkers install structural and reinforcing iron and steel to form and support buildings, bridges, and roads.

98.name: Flooring Installers and Tile and Marble Setters
98.brief: Flooring installers and tile and marble setters lay and finish carpet, wood, vinyl, and tile.
similar_occupations: Drywall and Ceiling Tile Installers, and Tapers

99.name: Adult Literacy and High School Equivalency Diploma Teachers
99.brief: Adult literacy and high school equivalency diploma teachers instruct adults in basic skills, such as reading, writing, and speaking English. They also help students earn their high school equivalent diploma.

100.name: Career and Technical Education Teachers
100.brief: Career and technical education teachers instruct students in various technical and vocational subjects, such as auto repair, healthcare, and culinary arts. They teach academic and technical content to provide students with the skills and knowledge necessary to enter an occupation.
similar_occupations: Elementary, Middle, and High School Principals

101.name: Archivists, Curators, and Museum Workers
101.brief: Archivists appraise, process, catalog, and preserve permanent records and historically valuable documents. Curators oversee collections of artwork and historic items, and may conduct public service activities for an institution. Museum technicians and conservators prepare and restore objects and documents in museum collections and exhibits.

102.name: High School Teachers
102.brief: High school teachers help prepare students for life after graduation. They teach academic lessons and various skills that students will need to attend college and to enter the job market.
similar_occupations: Elementary, Middle, and High School Principals

103.name: Instructional Coordinators
103.brief: Instructional coordinators oversee school curriculums and teaching standards. They develop instructional material, coordinate its implementation with teachers and principals, and assess its effectiveness.
similar_occupations: Elementary, Middle, and High School Principals

104.name: Kindergarten and Elementary School Teachers
104.brief: Kindergarten and elementary school teachers prepare younger students for future schooling by teaching them basic subjects such as math and reading.
similar_occupations: Elementary, Middle, and High School Principals

105.name: Librarians
105.brief: Librarians help people find information and conduct research for personal and professional use. Their job duties may change based on the type of library they work in, such as public, school, and medical libraries.
similar_occupations: Adult Literacy and High School Equivalency Diploma Teachers
Health Educators and Community Health Workers

106.name: Library Technicians and Assistants
106.brief: Library technicians and assistants help librarians with all aspects of running a library. They assist patrons, organize library materials and information, and perform clerical and administrative tasks.
similar_occupations: Medical Records and Health Information Technicians

107.name: Middle School Teachers
107.brief: Middle school teachers educate students, typically in sixth through eighth grades. Middle school teachers help students build on the fundamentals they learned in elementary school and prepare them for the more difficult curriculum they will face in high school.
similar_occupations: Elementary, Middle, and High School Principals

108.name: Postsecondary Teachers
108.brief: Postsecondary teachers instruct students in a wide variety of academic and career and technical subjects beyond the high school level. They also conduct research and publish scholarly papers and books.

109.name: Preschool Teachers
109.brief: Preschool teachers educate and care for children younger than age 5 who have not yet entered kindergarten. They teach reading, writing, science, and other subjects in a way that young children can understand.

110.name: Special Education Teachers
110.brief: Special education teachers work with students who have a wide range of learning, mental, emotional, and physical disabilities. They adapt general education lessons and teach various subjects, such as reading, writing, and math, to students with mild and moderate disabilities. They also teach basic skills, such as literacy and communication techniques, to students with severe disabilities.
similar_occupations: Elementary, Middle, and High School Principals

111.name: Teacher Assistants
111.brief: Teacher assistants work under a teacherâs supervision to give students additional attention and instruction.

112.name: Actors
112.brief: Actors express ideas and portray characters in theater, film, television, and other performing arts media. They interpret a writerâs script to entertain or inform an audience.
similar_occupations: Film and Video Editors and Camera Operators

113.name: Athletes and Sports Competitors
113.brief: Athletes and sports competitors participate in organized, officiated sporting events to entertain spectators.
similar_occupations: Umpires, Referees, and Other Sports Officials

114.name: Coaches and Scouts
114.brief: Coaches teach amateur or professional athletes the skills they need to succeed at their sport. Scouts look for new players and evaluate their skills and likelihood for success at the college, amateur, or professional level. Many coaches are also involved in scouting.
similar_occupations: Umpires, Referees, and Other Sports Officials

115.name: Dancers and Choreographers
115.brief: Dancers and choreographers use dance performances to express ideas and stories. There are many types of dance, such as ballet, tango, modern dance, tap, and jazz.

117.name: Musicians and Singers
117.brief: Musicians and singers play instruments or sing for live audiences and in recording studios.

118.name: Producers and Directors
118.brief: Producers and directors create motion pictures, television shows, live theater, commercials, and other performing arts productions. They interpret a writerâs script to entertain or inform an audience.
similar_occupations: Film and Video Editors and Camera Operators

119.name: Umpires, Referees, and Other Sports Officials
119.brief: Umpires, referees, and other sports officials preside over competitive athletic or sporting events to help maintain standards of play. They detect infractions and decide penalties according to the rules of the game.

120.name: Agricultural Workers
120.brief: Agricultural workers maintain the quality of farms, crops, and livestock by operating machinery and doing physical labor under the supervision of farmers, ranchers, and other agricultural managers.
similar_occupations: Farmers, Ranchers, and Other Agricultural Managers

121.name: Fishing and Hunting Workers
121.brief: Fishing and hunting workers catch and trap various types of animal life. The fish and wild animals they catch are for human food, animal feed, bait, and other uses.

122.name: Forest and Conservation Workers
122.brief: Forest and conservation workers measure and improve the quality of forests. Under the supervision of foresters and forest and conservation technicians, they develop, maintain, and protect forests.

123.name: Logging Workers
123.brief: Logging workers harvest thousands of acres of forests each year. The timber they harvest provides the raw material for many consumer goods and industrial products.

124.name: Bartenders
124.brief: Bartenders mix drinks and serve them directly to customers or through wait staff.
similar_occupations: Food and Beverage Serving and Related Workers

125.name: Chefs and Head Cooks
125.brief: Chefs and head cooks oversee the daily food preparation at restaurants and other places where food is served. They direct kitchen staff and handle any food-related concerns.
similar_occupations: Food and Beverage Serving and Related Workers

126.name: Cooks
126.brief: Cooks prepare, season, and cook a wide range of foods, which may include soups, salads, entrees, and desserts.
similar_occupations: Food and Beverage Serving and Related Workers

127.name: Food and Beverage Serving and Related Workers
127.brief: Food and beverage serving and related workers perform a variety of customer service, food preparation, and cleaning duties in restaurants, cafeterias, and other eating and drinking establishments.

128.name: Food Preparation Workers
128.brief: Food preparation workers perform many routine tasks under the direction of cooks, chefs, or food service managers. Food preparation workers prepare cold foods, slice meat, peel and cut vegetables, brew coffee or tea, and perform many other food service tasks.
similar_occupations: Food and Beverage Serving and Related Workers

129.name: Waiters and Waitresses
129.brief: Waiters and waitresses take orders and serve food and beverages to customers in dining establishments.
similar_occupations: Food and Beverage Serving and Related Workers

130.name: Athletic Trainers
130.brief: Athletic trainers specialize in preventing, diagnosing, and treating muscle and bone injuries and illnesses.

131.name: Audiologists
131.brief: Audiologists diagnose, manage, and treat a patientâs hearing, balance, or ear problems.

132.name: Chiropractors
132.brief: Chiropractors treat patients with health problems of the neuromusculoskeletal system, which includes nerves, bones, muscles, ligaments, and tendons. They use spinal adjustments and manipulation, and other techniques to manage patientsâ health concerns, such as back and neck pain.

133.name: Dental Assistants
133.brief: Dental assistants perform many tasks, ranging from providing patient care and taking x rays to recordkeeping and scheduling appointments. Their duties vary by state and by the dentistsâ offices where they work.

134.name: Dental Hygienists
134.brief: Dental hygienists clean teeth, examine patients for signs of oral diseases such as gingivitis, and provide other preventive dental care. They also educate patients on ways to improve and maintain good oral health.

135.name: Dentists
135.brief: Dentists diagnose and treat problems with patientsâ teeth, gums, and related parts of the mouth. They provide advice and instruction on taking care of the teeth and gums and on diet choices that affect oral health.

136.name: Diagnostic Medical Sonographers and Cardiovascular Technologists and Technicians, Including Vascular Technologists
136.brief: Diagnostic medical sonographers and cardiovascular technologists and technicians, including vascular technologists, operate special imaging equipment to create images or to conduct tests. The images and test results help physicians assess and diagnose medical conditions. Some technologists assist physicians and surgeons during surgical procedures.
similar_occupations: Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians

137.name: Dietitians and Nutritionists
137.brief: Dietitians and nutritionists are experts in the use of food and nutrition to promote health and manage disease. They advise people on what to eat in order to lead a healthy lifestyle or achieve a specific health-related goal.
similar_occupations: Health Educators and Community Health Workers

138.name: EMTs and Paramedics
138.brief: Emergency medical technicians (EMTs) and paramedics care for the sick or injured in emergency medical settings. Peopleâs lives often depend on the quick reaction and competent care provided by these workers. EMTs and paramedics respond to emergency calls, performing medical services and transporting patients to medical facilities.

139.name: Exercise Physiologists
139.brief: Exercise physiologists develop fitness and exercise programs that help patients recover from chronic diseases and improve cardiovascular function, body composition, and flexibility.

140.name: Genetic Counselors
140.brief: Genetic counselors assess individual or family risk for a variety of inherited conditions, such as genetic disorders and birth defects. They provide information and support to other healthcare providers, or to individuals and families concerned with the risk of inherited conditions.
similar_occupations: Health Educators and Community Health Workers
Mental Health Counselors and Marriage and Family Therapists

141.name: Home Health Aides
141.brief: Home health aides help people with disabilities, chronic illness, or cognitive impairment with activities of daily living. They often help older adults who need assistance. In some states, home health aides may be able to give a client medication or check the clientâs vital signs under the direction of a nurse or other healthcare practitioner.
similar_occupations: Licensed Practical and Licensed Vocational Nurses

142.name: Licensed Practical and Licensed Vocational Nurses
142.brief: Licensed practical nurses (LPNs) and licensed vocational nurses (LVNs) provide basic nursing care. They work under the direction of registered nurses and doctors.

143.name: Massage Therapists
143.brief: Massage therapists treat clients by using touch to manipulate the muscles and other soft tissues of the body. With their touch, therapists relieve pain, help heal injuries, improve circulation, relieve stress, increase relaxation, and aid in the general wellness of clients.

144.name: Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians

145.name: Medical Assistants
145.brief: Medical assistants complete administrative and clinical tasks in the offices of physicians, hospitals, and other healthcare facilities. Their duties vary with the location, specialty, and size of the practice.
similar_occupations: Licensed Practical and Licensed Vocational Nurses
Medical Records and Health Information Technicians

146.name: Medical Records and Health Information Technicians

147.name: Medical Transcriptionists
similar_occupations: Medical Records and Health Information Technicians

148.name: Nuclear Medicine Technologists
148.brief: Nuclear medicine technologists operate equipment that creates images of areas of a patientâs body. They prepare radioactive drugs and administer them to patients. The radioactive drugs cause abnormal areas of the body to appear different from normal areas in the images.
similar_occupations: Diagnostic Medical Sonographers and Cardiovascular Technologists and Technicians, Including Vascular Technologists
Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians

149.name: Nurse Anesthetists, Nurse Midwives, and Nurse Practitioners

150.name: Nursing Assistants and Orderlies
similar_occupations: Licensed Practical and Licensed Vocational Nurses

151.name: Occupational Health and Safety Specialists
151.brief: Occupational health and safety specialists analyze many types of work environments and work procedures. Specialists inspect workplaces for adherence to regulations on safety, health, and the environment. They also design programs to prevent disease or injury to workers and damage to the environment.

152.name: Occupational Health and Safety Technicians
152.brief: Occupational health and safety technicians collect data on the health and safety conditions of the workplace. Technicians work with occupational health and safety specialists in conducting tests and measuring hazards to help prevent harm to workers, property, the environment, and the general public.

153.name: Occupational Therapists
153.brief: Occupational therapists treat injured, ill, or disabled patients through the therapeutic use of everyday activities. They help these patients develop, recover, and improve the skills needed for daily living and working.

154.name: Occupational Therapy Assistants and Aides
154.brief: Occupational therapy assistants and aides help patients develop, recover, and improve the skills needed for daily living and working. Occupational therapy assistants are directly involved in providing therapy to patients; occupational therapy aides typically perform support activities. Both assistants and aides work under the direction of occupational therapists.

155.name: Opticians, Dispensing
155.brief: Dispensing opticians help fit eyeglasses and contact lenses, following prescriptions from ophthalmologists and optometrists. They also help customers decide which eyeglass frames or contact lenses to buy.
similar_occupations: Dental and Ophthalmic Laboratory Technicians and Medical Appliance Technicians
Jewelers and Precious Stone and Metal Workers

156.name: Optometrists
156.brief: Optometrists examine the eyes and other parts of the visual system. They also diagnose and treat visual problems and manage diseases, injuries, and other disorders of the eyes. They prescribe eyeglasses or contact lenses as needed.

157.name: Orthotists and Prosthetists
157.brief: Orthotists and prosthetists design and fabricate medical supportive devices and measure and fit patients for them. These devices include artificial limbs (arms, hands, legs, and feet), braces, and other medical or surgical devices.
similar_occupations: Dental and Ophthalmic Laboratory Technicians and Medical Appliance Technicians

158.name: Pharmacists
158.brief: Pharmacists dispense prescription medications to patients and offer expertise in the safe use of prescriptions. They also may conduct health and wellness screenings, provide immunizations, oversee the medications given to patients, and provide advice on healthy lifestyles.

159.name: Pharmacy Technicians
159.brief: Pharmacy technicians help pharmacists dispense prescription medication to customers or health professionals.
similar_occupations: Medical Records and Health Information Technicians

160.name: Phlebotomists
160.brief: Phlebotomists draw blood for tests, transfusions, research, or blood donations. Some explain their work to patients and provide assistance when patients have adverse reactions after their blood is drawn.
similar_occupations: Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians
Medical Records and Health Information Technicians
Veterinary Assistants and Laboratory Animal Caretakers

163.name: Physician Assistants
similar_occupations: Nurse Anesthetists, Nurse Midwives, and Nurse Practitioners

164.name: Physicians and Surgeons
164.brief: Physicians and surgeons diagnose and treat injuries or illnesses. Physicians examine patients; take medical histories; prescribe medications; and order, perform, and interpret diagnostic tests. They counsel patients on diet, hygiene, and preventive healthcare. Surgeons operate on patients to treat injuries, such as broken bones; diseases, such as cancerous tumors; and deformities, such as cleft palates.
similar_occupations: Nurse Anesthetists, Nurse Midwives, and Nurse Practitioners

165.name: Podiatrists
165.brief: Podiatrists provide medical care for people with foot, ankle, and lower leg problems. They diagnose illnesses, treat injuries, and perform surgery involving the lower extremities.

166.name: Psychiatric Technicians and Aides
166.brief: Psychiatric technicians and aides care for people who have mental illness and developmental disabilities. Technicians typically provide therapeutic care and monitor their patientsâ conditions. Aides help patients in their daily activities and ensure a safe, clean environment.
similar_occupations: Licensed Practical and Licensed Vocational Nurses

167.name: Radiation Therapists
167.brief: Radiation therapists treat cancer and other diseases in patients by administering radiation treatments.
similar_occupations: Diagnostic Medical Sonographers and Cardiovascular Technologists and Technicians, Including Vascular Technologists

168.name: Radiologic and MRI Technologists
similar_occupations: Diagnostic Medical Sonographers and Cardiovascular Technologists and Technicians, Including Vascular Technologists

169.name: Recreational Therapists
169.brief: Recreational therapists plan, direct, and coordinate recreation-based treatment programs for people with disabilities, injuries, or illnesses. These therapists use a variety of modalities, including arts and crafts; drama, music, and dance; sports and games; aquatics; and community outings to help maintain or improve a patientâs physical, social, and emotional well-being.

170.name: Registered Nurses
170.brief: Registered nurses (RNs) provide and coordinate patient care, educate patients and the public about various health conditions, and provide advice and emotional support to patients and their family members.
similar_occupations: Diagnostic Medical Sonographers and Cardiovascular Technologists and Technicians, Including Vascular Technologists
Licensed Practical and Licensed Vocational Nurses
Nurse Anesthetists, Nurse Midwives, and Nurse Practitioners

171.name: Respiratory Therapists
171.brief: Respiratory therapists care for patients who have trouble breathingâfor example, from a chronic respiratory disease, such as asthma or emphysema. Their patients range from premature infants with undeveloped lungs to elderly patients who have diseased lungs. They also provide emergency care to patients suffering from heart attacks, drowning, or shock.

173.name: Surgical Technologists
similar_occupations: Licensed Practical and Licensed Vocational Nurses
Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians

174.name: Veterinarians
174.brief: Veterinarians care for the health of animals and work to improve public health. They diagnose, treat, and research medical conditions and diseases of pets, livestock, and other animals.
similar_occupations: Veterinary Assistants and Laboratory Animal Caretakers

175.name: Veterinary Assistants and Laboratory Animal Caretakers
175.brief: Veterinary assistants and laboratory animal caretakers look after animals in laboratories, animal hospitals, and clinics. They care for the animals by performing routine tasks under the supervision of scientists, veterinarians, and veterinary technologists and technicians.

176.name: Veterinary Technologists and Technicians
176.brief: Veterinary technologists and technicians perform medical tests under the supervision of a licensed veterinarian to assist in diagnosing the injuries and illnesses of animals.
similar_occupations: Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians
Veterinary Assistants and Laboratory Animal Caretakers

177.name: Aircraft and Avionics Equipment Mechanics and Technicians
177.brief: Aircraft and avionics equipment mechanics and technicians repair and perform scheduled maintenance on aircraft. They also may perform aircraft inspections as required by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA).
similar_occupations: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers
Heavy Vehicle and Mobile Equipment Service Technicians

178.name: Automotive Body and Glass Repairers
178.brief: Automotive body and glass repairers restore, refinish, and replace vehicle bodies and frames, windshields, and window glass.
similar_occupations: Heavy Vehicle and Mobile Equipment Service Technicians

179.name: Automotive Service Technicians and Mechanics
similar_occupations: Heavy Vehicle and Mobile Equipment Service Technicians

180.name: Diesel Service Technicians and Mechanics
180.brief: Diesel service technicians and mechanics inspect, repair, and overhaul buses and trucks, or maintain and repair any type of diesel engine.
similar_occupations: Aircraft and Avionics Equipment Mechanics and Technicians
Heavy Vehicle and Mobile Equipment Service Technicians

181.name: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers
181.brief: Electrical and electronics installers and repairers install or repair a variety of electrical equipment in telecommunications, transportation, utilities, and other industries.
similar_occupations: Aircraft and Avionics Equipment Mechanics and Technicians

182.name: General Maintenance and Repair Workers
182.brief: General maintenance and repair workers fix and maintain machines, mechanical equipment, and buildings. They paint, repair flooring, and work on plumbing, electrical, and air-conditioning and heating systems.
similar_occupations: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers
Heating, Air Conditioning, and Refrigeration Mechanics and Installers

183.name: Heating, Air Conditioning, and Refrigeration Mechanics and Installers

184.name: Heavy Vehicle and Mobile Equipment Service Technicians
184.brief: Heavy vehicle and mobile equipment service technicians inspect, maintain, and repair vehicles and machinery used in construction, farming, rail transportation, and other industries.
similar_occupations: Aircraft and Avionics Equipment Mechanics and Technicians
Industrial Machinery Mechanics, Machinery Maintenance Workers, and Millwrights

185.name: Industrial Machinery Mechanics, Machinery Maintenance Workers, and Millwrights
similar_occupations: Machinists and Tool and Die Makers

186.name: Line Installers and Repairers
similar_occupations: Power Plant Operators, Distributors, and Dispatchers

187.name: Medical Equipment Repairers
187.brief: Medical equipment repairers install, maintain, and repair patient care equipment.
similar_occupations: Aircraft and Avionics Equipment Mechanics and Technicians
Industrial Machinery Mechanics, Machinery Maintenance Workers, and Millwrights
Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians

188.name: Small Engine Mechanics
188.brief: Small engine mechanics inspect, service, and repair motorized power equipment. Mechanics often specialize in one type of equipment, such as motorcycles, motorboats, or outdoor power equipment.
similar_occupations: Heavy Vehicle and Mobile Equipment Service Technicians

190.name: Wind Turbine Technicians
similar_occupations: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers
Heating, Air Conditioning, and Refrigeration Mechanics and Installers
Industrial Machinery Mechanics, Machinery Maintenance Workers, and Millwrights

191.name: Arbitrators, Mediators, and Conciliators
191.brief: Arbitrators, mediators, and conciliators facilitate negotiation and dialogue between disputing parties to help resolve conflicts outside of the court system.

192.name: Court Reporters
192.brief: Court reporters create word-for-word transcriptions at trials, depositions, and other legal proceedings. Some court reporters provide captioning for television and real-time translation for deaf or hard-of-hearing people at public events, in business meetings, or in classrooms.

193.name: Judges and Hearing Officers
193.brief: Judges and hearing officers apply the law by overseeing the legal process in courts. They also conduct pretrial hearings, resolve administrative disputes, facilitate negotiations between opposing parties, and issue legal decisions.

194.name: Lawyers
194.brief: Lawyers advise and represent individuals, businesses, and government agencies on legal issues and disputes.

195.name: Paralegals and Legal Assistants
195.brief: Paralegals and legal assistants do a variety of tasks to support lawyers, including maintaining and organizing files, conducting legal research, and drafting documents.
similar_occupations: Claims Adjusters, Appraisers, Examiners, and Investigators

196.name: Agricultural and Food Science Technicians
196.brief: Agricultural and food science technicians assist agricultural and food scientists by performing duties such as measuring and analyzing the quality of food and agricultural products.
similar_occupations: Farmers, Ranchers, and Other Agricultural Managers

197.name: Agricultural and Food Scientists
197.brief: Agricultural and food scientists research ways to improve the efficiency and safety of agricultural establishments and products.
similar_occupations: Farmers, Ranchers, and Other Agricultural Managers

198.name: Anthropologists and Archeologists
198.brief: Anthropologists and archeologists study the origin, development, and behavior of humans. They examine the cultures, languages, archeological remains, and physical characteristics of people in various parts of the world.

199.name: Atmospheric Scientists, Including Meteorologists
199.brief: Atmospheric scientists study the weather and climate, and how those conditions affect human activity and the earth in general.

200.name: Biochemists and Biophysicists
200.brief: Biochemists and biophysicists study the chemical and physical principles of living things and of biological processes, such as cell development, growth, heredity, and disease.

201.name: Biological Technicians
201.brief: Biological technicians help biological and medical scientists conduct laboratory tests and experiments.
similar_occupations: Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians

202.name: Chemical Technicians
202.brief: Chemical technicians use special instruments and techniques to help chemists and chemical engineers research, develop, produce, and test chemical products and processes.
similar_occupations: Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians

203.name: Chemists and Materials Scientists
203.brief: Chemists and materials scientists study substances at the atomic and molecular levels and the ways in which the substances interact with one another. They use their knowledge to develop new and improved products and to test the quality of manufactured goods.

204.name: Conservation Scientists and Foresters
204.brief: Conservation scientists and foresters manage the overall land quality of forests, parks, rangelands, and other natural resources.

205.name: Economists
205.brief: Economists study the production and distribution of resources, goods, and services by collecting and analyzing data, researching trends, and evaluating economic issues.

206.name: Environmental Science and Protection Technicians
206.brief: Environmental science and protection technicians monitor the environment and investigate sources of pollution and contamination, including those affecting public health. In addition, they work to ensure that environmental violations are prevented.
similar_occupations: Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians

207.name: Environmental Scientists and Specialists
207.brief: Environmental scientists and specialists use their knowledge of the natural sciences to protect the environment and human health. They may clean up polluted areas, advise policymakers, or work with industry to reduce waste.

208.name: Epidemiologists
208.brief: Epidemiologists are public health professionals who investigate patterns and causes of disease and injury in humans. They seek to reduce the risk and occurrence of negative health outcomes through research, community education, and health policy.
similar_occupations: Health Educators and Community Health Workers

209.name: Forensic Science Technicians
209.brief: Forensic science technicians aid criminal investigations by collecting and analyzing evidence. Many technicians specialize in either crime scene investigation or laboratory analysis. Most forensic science technicians spend some time writing reports.
similar_occupations: Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians

210.name: Geographers
210.brief: Geographers study the Earth and its land, features, and inhabitants. They also examine phenomena such as political or cultural structures and study the physical and human geographic characteristics of regions ranging in scale from local to global.

211.name: Geological and Petroleum Technicians
211.brief: Geological and petroleum technicians provide support to scientists and engineers in exploring and extracting natural resources, such as minerals, oil, and natural gas.

212.name: Geoscientists
212.brief: Geoscientists study the physical aspects of the Earth, such as its composition, structure, and processes, to learn about its past, present, and future.

213.name: Historians
213.brief: Historians research, analyze, interpret, and present the past by studying historical documents and sources.

214.name: Hydrologists
214.brief: Hydrologists study how water moves across and through the Earthâs crust. They use their expertise to solve problems in the areas of water quality or availability.

215.name: Medical Scientists
215.brief: Medical scientists conduct research aimed at improving overall human health. They often use clinical trials and other investigative methods to reach their findings.
similar_occupations: Health Educators and Community Health Workers
Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians

216.name: Microbiologists
216.brief: Microbiologists study microorganisms such as bacteria, viruses, algae, fungi, and some types of parasites. They try to understand how these organisms live, grow, and interact with their environments.
similar_occupations: Medical and Clinical Laboratory Technologists and Technicians

217.name: Nuclear Technicians
217.brief: Nuclear technicians assist physicists, engineers, and other professionals in nuclear research and nuclear energy production. They operate special equipment used in these activities and monitor the levels of radiation that are produced.
similar_occupations: Power Plant Operators, Distributors, and Dispatchers

218.name: Physicists and Astronomers
218.brief: Physicists and astronomers study the ways in which various forms of matter and energy interact. Theoretical physicists and astronomers may study the nature of time or the origin of the universe. Some physicists design and perform experiments with sophisticated equipment such as particle accelerators, electron microscopes, and lasers.

219.name: Political Scientists
219.brief: Political scientists study the origin, development, and operation of political systems. They research political ideas and analyze governments, policies, political trends, and related issues.

220.name: Psychologists
220.brief: Psychologists study cognitive, emotional, and social processes and behavior by observing, interpreting, and recording how people relate to one another and their environments.
similar_occupations: Mental Health Counselors and Marriage and Family Therapists
Substance Abuse and Behavioral Disorder Counselors

221.name: Sociologists
221.brief: Sociologists study society and social behavior by examining the groups, cultures, organizations, social institutions, and processes that develop when people interact and work together.

222.name: Survey Researchers
222.brief: Survey researchers design and conduct surveys and analyze data. Surveys are used to collect factual data, such as employment and salary information, or to ask questions in order to understand peopleâs opinions, preferences, beliefs, or desires.

223.name: Urban and Regional Planners
223.brief: Urban and regional planners develop land use plans and programs that help create communities, accommodate population growth, and revitalize physical facilities in towns, cities, counties, and metropolitan areas.

224.name: Zoologists and Wildlife Biologists
224.brief: Zoologists and wildlife biologists study animals and other wildlife and how they interact with their ecosystems. They study the physical characteristics of animals, animal behaviors, and the impacts humans have on wildlife and natural habitats.

225.name: Administrative Services Managers
225.brief: Administrative services managers plan, direct, and coordinate supportive services of an organization. Their specific responsibilities vary, but administrative service managers typically maintain facilities and supervise activities that include recordkeeping, mail distribution, and office upkeep.
similar_occupations: Property, Real Estate, and Community Association Managers

226.name: Advertising, Promotions, and Marketing Managers
226.brief: Advertising, promotions, and marketing managers plan programs to generate interest in products or services. They work with art directors, sales agents, and financial staff members.

227.name: Architectural and Engineering Managers
227.brief: Architectural and engineering managers plan, direct, and coordinate activities in architectural and engineering companies.

228.name: Compensation and Benefits Managers
228.brief: Compensation managers plan, develop, and oversee programs to determine how much an organization pays its employees and how employees are paid. Benefits managers plan, direct, and coordinate retirement plans, health insurance, and other benefits that an organization offers its employees.
similar_occupations: Compensation, Benefits, and Job Analysis Specialists

229.name: Computer and Information Systems Managers
229.brief: Computer and information systems managers, often called information technology (IT) managers or IT project managers, plan, coordinate, and direct computer-related activities in an organization. They help determine the information technology goals of an organization and are responsible for implementing computer systems to meet those goals.

230.name: Construction Managers
230.brief: Construction managers plan, coordinate, budget, and supervise construction projects from start to finish.

231.name: Elementary, Middle, and High School Principals
231.brief: Elementary, middle, and high school principals manage all school operations, including daily school activities. They coordinate curricula, oversee teachers and other school staff, and provide a safe and productive learning environment for students.

232.name: Emergency Management Directors
232.brief: Emergency management directors prepare plans and procedures for responding to natural disasters or other emergencies. They also help lead the response during and after emergencies, often in coordination with public safety officials, elected officials, nonprofit organizations, and government agencies.

233.name: Farmers, Ranchers, and Other Agricultural Managers
233.brief: Farmers, ranchers, and other agricultural managers operate establishments that produce crops, livestock, and dairy products.

234.name: Financial Managers
234.brief: Financial managers are responsible for the financial health of an organization. They produce financial reports, direct investment activities, and develop strategies and plans for the long-term financial goals of their organization.

235.name: Food Service Managers
235.brief: Food service managers are responsible for the daily operation of restaurants and other establishments that prepare and serve food and beverages. They direct staff to ensure that customers are satisfied with their dining experience, and they manage the business to ensure that it is profitable.

236.name: Human Resources Managers
236.brief: Human resources managers plan, direct, and coordinate the administrative functions of an organization. They oversee the recruiting, interviewing, and hiring of new staff; consult with top executives on strategic planning; and serve as a link between an organizationâs management and its employees.
similar_occupations: Compensation, Benefits, and Job Analysis Specialists

237.name: Industrial Production Managers
237.brief: Industrial production managers oversee the daily operations of manufacturing and related plants. They coordinate, plan, and direct the activities used to create a wide range of goods, such as cars, computer equipment, or paper products.

238.name: Lodging Managers
238.brief: Lodging managers ensure that guests on vacation or business travel have a pleasant experience at a hotel, motel, or other types of establishment with accommodations. They also ensure that the establishment is run efficiently and profitably.
similar_occupations: Property, Real Estate, and Community Association Managers

240.name: Natural Sciences Managers
240.brief: Natural sciences managers supervise the work of scientists, including chemists, physicists, and biologists. They direct activities related to research and development, and coordinate activities such as testing, quality control, and production.

241.name: Postsecondary Education Administrators
241.brief: Postsecondary education administrators oversee student services, academics, and faculty research at colleges and universities. Their job duties vary depending on the area of the college they manage, such as admissions, student life, or the office of the registrar.

242.name: Preschool and Childcare Center Directors
242.brief: Preschool and childcare center directors supervise and lead staffs, oversee daily activities, design curriculums, and prepare budgets. They are responsible for all aspects of their centerâs program.

243.name: Property, Real Estate, and Community Association Managers
243.brief: Property, real estate, and community association managers take care of the many aspects of residential, commercial, or industrial properties. They make sure the property is well maintained, has a nice appearance, and preserves its resale or leasing value.
similar_occupations: Real Estate Brokers and Sales Agents

244.name: Public Relations and Fundraising Managers
244.brief: Public relations managers plan and direct the creation of material that will maintain or enhance the public image of their employer or client. Fundraising managers coordinate campaigns that bring in donations for their organization.

245.name: Purchasing Managers
245.brief: Purchasing managers plan, direct, and coordinate the buying of materials, products, or services for wholesalers, retailers, or organizations. They oversee the work of procurement-related occupations including buyers and purchasing agents.

246.name: Sales Managers
246.brief: Sales managers direct organizations' sales teams. They set sales goals, analyze data, and develop training programs for organizationsâ sales representatives.

247.name: Social and Community Service Managers
247.brief: Social and community service managers coordinate and supervise social service programs and community organizations. They manage staff who provide social services to the public.
similar_occupations: Health Educators and Community Health Workers
Mental Health Counselors and Marriage and Family Therapists
Probation Officers and Correctional Treatment Specialists
Substance Abuse and Behavioral Disorder Counselors

248.name: Top Executives
248.brief: Top executives devise strategies and policies to ensure that an organization meets its goals. They plan, direct, and coordinate operational activities of companies and organizations.

249.name: Training and Development Managers
249.brief: Training and development managers plan, direct, and coordinate programs to enhance the knowledge and skills of an organizationâs employees. They also oversee a staff of training and development specialists.
similar_occupations: Compensation, Benefits, and Job Analysis Specialists

250.name: Actuaries
250.brief: Actuaries analyze the financial costs of risk and uncertainty. They use mathematics, statistics, and financial theory to assess the risk that an event will occur, and they help businesses and clients develop policies that minimize the cost of that risk. Actuariesâ work is essential to the insurance industry.

251.name: Mathematicians
251.brief: Mathematicians conduct research to develop and understand mathematical principles. They also analyze data and apply mathematical techniques to help solve real-world problems.

252.name: Operations Research Analysts
252.brief: Operations research analysts use advanced mathematical and analytical methods to help organizations investigate complex issues, identify and solve problems, and make better decisions.

253.name: Statisticians
253.brief: Statisticians use statistical methods to collect and analyze data and to help solve real-world problems in business, engineering, healthcare, or other fields.

254.name: Announcers
254.brief: Announcers present music, news, and sports and may provide commentary or interview guests about these or other important topics. Some act as masters of ceremonies (emcees) or disc jockeys (DJs) at weddings, parties, or clubs.
similar_occupations: Reporters, Correspondents, and Broadcast News Analysts

255.name: Broadcast and Sound Engineering Technicians
255.brief: Broadcast and sound engineering technicians set up, operate, and maintain the electrical equipment for radio programs, television broadcasts, concerts, sound recordings, and movies.
similar_occupations: Electrical and Electronics Installers and Repairers
Film and Video Editors and Camera Operators

256.name: Editors
256.brief: Editors plan, review, and revise content for publication.
similar_occupations: Reporters, Correspondents, and Broadcast News Analysts

257.name: Film and Video Editors and Camera Operators
257.brief: Film and video editors and camera operators manipulate moving images that entertain or inform an audience.
similar_occupations: Reporters, Correspondents, and Broadcast News Analysts

258.name: Interpreters and Translators
258.brief: Interpreters and translators convert information from one language into another language. Interpreters work in spoken or sign language; translators work in written language.
similar_occupations: Adult Literacy and High School Equivalency Diploma Teachers

259.name: Photographers
259.brief: Photographers use their technical expertise, creativity, and composition skills to produce and preserve images that tell a story or record an event.
similar_occupations: Film and Video Editors and Camera Operators
Reporters, Correspondents, and Broadcast News Analysts

260.name: Public Relations Specialists
260.brief: Public relations specialists create and maintain a favorable public image for the organization they represent. They design media releases to shape public perception of their organization and to increase awareness of its work and goals.

261.name: Reporters, Correspondents, and Broadcast News Analysts
261.brief: Reporters, correspondents, and broadcast news analysts inform the public about news and events happening internationally, nationally, and locally. They report the news for newspapers, magazines, websites, television, and radio.
similar_occupations: Film and Video Editors and Camera Operators

263.name: Writers and Authors
263.brief: Writers and authors develop written content for advertisements, books, magazines, movie and television scripts, songs, blogs, or other types of media.
similar_occupations: Reporters, Correspondents, and Broadcast News Analysts

264.name: Bill and Account Collectors
264.brief: Bill and account collectors try to recover payment on overdue bills. They negotiate repayment plans with debtors and help them find solutions to make paying their overdue bills easier.

265.name: Bookkeeping, Accounting, and Auditing Clerks
265.brief: Bookkeeping, accounting, and auditing clerks produce financial records for organizations. They record financial transactions, update statements, and check financial records for accuracy.
similar_occupations: Tax Examiners and Collectors, and Revenue Agents

266.name: Customer Service Representatives
266.brief: Customer service representatives interact with customers to handle complaints, process orders, and provide information about an organizationâs products and services.

267.name: Desktop Publishers
267.brief: Desktop publishers use computer software to design page layouts for newspapers, books, brochures, and other items that are printed or published online.
similar_occupations: Film and Video Editors and Camera Operators

268.name: Financial Clerks
268.brief: Financial clerks do administrative work for many types of organizations. They keep records, help customers, and carry out financial transactions.
similar_occupations: Medical Records and Health Information Technicians

269.name: General Office Clerks
269.brief: General office clerks perform a variety of clerical tasks, including answering telephones, typing documents, and filing records.

270.name: Information Clerks
270.brief: Information clerks perform routine clerical duties such as maintaining records, collecting data, and providing information to customers.

271.name: Material Recording Clerks
271.brief: Material recording clerks track product information in order to keep businesses and supply chains on schedule. They ensure proper scheduling, recordkeeping, and inventory control.

273.name: Postal Service Workers
273.brief: Postal service workers sell postal products and collect, sort, and deliver mail.
similar_occupations: Delivery Truck Drivers and Driver/Sales Workers

274.name: Receptionists
274.brief: Receptionists perform administrative tasks, such as answering phones, receiving visitors, and providing general information about their organization to the public and customers.

275.name: Secretaries and Administrative Assistants
275.brief: Secretaries and administrative assistants perform clerical and administrative duties. They organize files, prepare documents, schedule appointments, and support other staff.
similar_occupations: Medical Records and Health Information Technicians

276.name: Tellers
276.brief: Tellers are responsible for accurately processing routine transactions at a bank. These transactions include cashing checks, depositing money, and collecting loan payments.

277.name: Animal Care and Service Workers
277.brief: Animal care and service workers provide care for animals. They feed, groom, bathe, and exercise pets and other nonfarm animals. Job tasks vary by position and place of work.
similar_occupations: Farmers, Ranchers, and Other Agricultural Managers
Veterinary Assistants and Laboratory Animal Caretakers

278.name: Barbers, Hairdressers, and Cosmetologists
278.brief: Barbers, hairdressers, and cosmetologists provide haircutting, hairstyling, and a range of other beauty services.

279.name: Childcare Workers
279.brief: Childcare workers provide care for children when parents and other family members are unavailable. They attend to childrenâs basic needs, such as bathing and feeding. In addition, some help children prepare for kindergarten or help older children with homework.

280.name: Fitness Trainers and Instructors
280.brief: Fitness trainers and instructors lead, instruct, and motivate individuals or groups in exercise activities, including cardiovascular exercises (exercises for the heart and blood circulation), strength training, and stretching. They work with people of all ages and skill levels.

281.name: Funeral Service Workers
